label: [tcp] tcp-out node in reply mode
info: ## Multiple tcp in nodes Test checks for handling of `_session` value on the message. ## Setup Node tcp:1234 is a tcp listener, listening on port 1234 for incoming connections. Node tcp:localhost:1234 is a tcp-in node that *connects* to a server on *localhost* on port 1234, that is, it connects to tcp:1234. Since both nodes are tcp-in nodes, they *produce* messages but do not receive messages. A tcp-out node tcp: is used to create a message. This is tcp-out node set to **reply** mode meaning it needs a `_session` attribute on the message to know where to send messages it receives to. ## Test The inject node sends a "hello world" message to the tcp out node without a `_session` attribute on the message. ## Discussion If the tcp:localhost:1234 node is set to "single string" instead if "stream of strings", then it receives nothing. So it receives a message from the tcp-out node, sends it to the listener and the response with a "ok" and that is sent back to it. **NOTE**: the difference between single string and stream of strings is that the string is only sent once the [connection is dropped](https://github.com/node-red/node-red/blob/01815b995e1bf2c87a82afe1a51d563a2d83fe31/packages/node_modules/%40node-red/nodes/core/network/31-tcpin.js#L158-L168).
